abstract: SAC Capital Advisors will soon fade to black. | An unlikely alliance looks to check the power of activist investors. | Jos. A. Bank weighs a deal for Eddie Bauer. | Private equity is playing a major role in the defense industry.

lead_paragraph: SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund started by Steven A. Cohen, will soon cease to exist as Wall Street has known it. The firm, whose reputation is now intricately linked to an insider trading scandal, is in the midst of rebranding itself, including changing its name and corporate structure. And recently, a major bank distanced itself from the firm. Together, these developments provide the most vivid illustration yet of SAC’s steep fall from powerful hedge fund to marginalized player,  Ben Protess and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook.

headline.main: SAC Fashioning a New Identity

lead_paragraph: Nascar announced on Thursday changes to its end-of-season playoffs, the Sprint Cup Chase for the Championship. The changes, officials said, would place a greater emphasis on winning races. The old format pitted 12 drivers – the top 10 in points and two wild-card entries -- against one another in the final 10 races of the year in a runoff to decide the driving title. Jimmie Johnson, who won six races in 2013, collected his sixth championship, edging out Matt Kenseth, who had seven wins.

headline.main: Monday Motorsports: Nascar Announces Sprint Cup Chase Changes

lead_paragraph: I LOVE business travel. I mean, I seriously love it, because every time I leave my home that means I’m doing something to develop my company. I’m the founder and designer for my business, Clothing Arts. We make travel apparel, so I might be meeting with a new buyer or an existing buyer or visiting some place to get inspiration. I’m a former Wall Street trader, and now I’m in the clothing business. I love every second of it. One business trip was five days long, and I was in India for a few of them, then Canada, then back to India, and then home. It was great.

abstract: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013.
snippet: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013.
lead_paragraph: For the second year in a row, Toyota led the nation with the most vehicles recalled: nearly 5.3 million in 2013. The cars and trucks from Toyota and its Lexus brand were among the almost 22 million vehicles recalled last year in 632 recalls, according to figures released by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. That figure compares with nearly 16.4 million vehicles recalled in 2012 and is the highest number since 2004, when recalled vehicles hit 30.8 million. The Chrysler Group ranked second, with almost 4.7 million vehicles recalled in 36 actions; and Honda and its Acura brand were third, with 15 recalls involving almost 2.8 million vehicles.

headline.main: Toyota Is Reported With Most Recalls in 2013

abstract: The “Apology Watch” begins on the DealBook website. | A crowded courtroom heard closing arguments in the insider trading trial of a former SAC manager. | In Detroit bankruptcy, it is Wall Street vs. Main Street. | Stocks slumped Monday on disappointing economic data.
snippet: The “Apology Watch” begins on the DealBook website. | A crowded courtroom heard closing arguments in the insider trading trial of a former SAC manager. | In Detroit bankruptcy, it is Wall Street vs. Main Street. | Stocks slumped Monday on disappoi...
lead_paragraph: “What does saying ‘sorry’ mean when it’s tossed around with the frequency of a Justin Bieber scandal?” asks Andrew Ross Sorkin in the DealBook column. Almost every day, some prominent figure — a chief executive, a politician, an athlete — is apologizing for something — to say nothing of the average person. Are we in the midst of an apology crisis? To hear Dov Seidman talk about it, the answer is an emphatic yes. And in fact, Mr. Seidman is so sure that our mea culpas have become meaningless that he called for an “apology cease-fire” in front of several dozen chief executives and politicians at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline.main: Hold the Apologies

abstract: The changes require that the companies meet so-called good manufacturing practices, which include testing for contamination from pathogens.
snippet: The changes require that the companies meet so-called good manufacturing practices, which include testing for contamination from pathogens.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration updated safety requirements for producers of infant formula. The changes require companies to tighten their quality control procedures and reporting requirements. They also require that the companies meet so-called good manufacturing practices, which include testing for contamination from pathogens like salmonella. Most companies already meet those standards, but the rule will give the agency more control over enforcing them. The rule will also ensure that infant formula contains all federally required nutrients. The changes will be open to public comment for 45 days.

headline.main: F.D.A. Tightens Rules on Infant Formula

The case may be the last criminal case to emerge from a decade-long investigation of Steven A. Cohen and his SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Martoma, who is married and has three young children, is expected to face a prison sentence of seven to 10 years.

abstract: Mr. Ash and his brother, Jerome, developed the music shop their father founded into a chain of 46 stores nationwide.
snippet: Mr. Ash and his brother, Jerome, developed the music shop their father founded into a chain of 46 stores nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Sam Ash preferred playing the violin to being an entrepreneur, and he said no when his sons, Jerome and Paul, asked him to expand beyond his single musical instrument store in Brooklyn. But five years after Sam died in 1956, the sons opened the family’s first branch store, in Hempstead, N.Y. It was just the beginning.

headline.main: Paul Ash, Who Made Music Store a Chain, Dies at 84
headline.print_headline: Paul Ash, President of Music Store Chain, Dies at 84

abstract: A security freeze on your credit report from the three big credit bureaus will stop anyone from opening a new account in your name.
snippet: A security freeze on your credit report from the three big credit bureaus will stop anyone from opening a new account in your name.
lead_paragraph: The pattern with credit- and debit-card breaches tends to go something like this: A company like Target or Neiman Marcus announces that thieves may have stolen your card numbers or other information, then the company offers a year of credit-monitoring. But the chastened keeper of your personal data rarely if ever offers to pay for the most potent protection of all: A security freeze on the files that the three big credit bureaus keep on you.

headline.main: A Line of Defense Against the Theft of Personal Data
headline.print_headline: A Line of Defense Against the Theft of Personal Data

abstract: The S.E.C. may have helped create the problem it is now hoping to solve — where institutional investors say they are outgunned by high-frequency traders and individual investors are adrift, Steven M. Davidoff writes.

lead_paragraph: There are now at least 58 stock exchanges in the United States, many of them dark pools where the trades can be made anonymously. With institutional investors claiming they are outgunned by high-frequency traders, and individual investors adrift in fragmented markets, it’s no wonder that Mary Jo White, the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is moving to review and overhaul how stocks are traded. The issue is that the S.E.C. may have created the problem it is now hoping to solve.

lead_paragraph: Comcast’s deal machine has spit out a value destroyer. Digesting Time Warner Cable is ambitious even for a serial acquirer like Comcast’s chief executive, Brian Roberts. abstract: A new book by Stephen Roach says it’s time for the United States to be more of a producer and for China to be more of a consumer.
snippet: A new book by Stephen Roach says it’s time for the United States to be more of a producer and for China to be more of a consumer.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Roach proposes to remake the two largest economies on the globe, ours and China’s. For decades, he writes, the United States and China relied too much on a “marriage of convenience” that guaranteed China a huge market for its exports. In exchange, China gave American consumers a cornucopia of inexpensive products, while creating a willing buyer of the United States government’s swollen debt. But that marriage has played out, Mr. Roach says; it has warped the two economies, leaving them ill-equipped for further growth.

abstract: Is it possible to increase your chances of winning a seemingly random card game?
snippet: Is it possible to increase your chances of winning a seemingly random card game?
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by Steve Humble (aka Dr Maths), a mathematics educator from Newcastle University. The game starts with a standard 52-card deck of playing cards, which includes, obviously, 26 red cards and 26 black cards. At the start of a game, each player announces, one player after the other, a three-color sequence she will be watching for as the deck of cards is dealt out card by card. Cards are then dealt, and when a player’s sequence appears in a series of three consecutive cards, all cards in play are removed from the game as a winning trick. This continues until the full pack of 52 cards is exhausted. At the end, the player with the most tricks is declared the winner.

headline.main: Humble-Nishiyama Randomness Game

snippet: Kim Metcalf-Kupres, the chief marketing officer of Johnson Controls, is a fearless flier, but riding in a car with her husband can be different.
lead_paragraph: I’VE traveled most of my career, but until about five years ago, most of my business trips were domestic. I’m starting my 20th year with Johnson Controls, and as its chief marketing officer now, most of my trips are international. Whether I like flying is debatable. It’s probably fairer to say that I’ve gotten used to flying. At one time, I was a horrible “white-knuckle” flier, and now I’m just kind of numb to it. Takeoffs and landings don’t worry me as much anymore, and I don’t even think twice about turbulence.

headline.main: Happy to Fly, When the Alternative Is Driving Off a Cliff

The stock of the jewelry retailer Signet rose after it agreed to buy its smaller rival Zale at a 41 percent premium for an enterprise value, which includes debt, of $1.4 billion. That’s what happens when the cost savings effectively cover the purchase price. It makes the shareholder-unfriendly transactions involving Comcast and Jos. A. Bank all the more noticeable.

abstract: Facebook’s deal to acquire WhatsApp shows that competition has never been more intense between technology companies fighting for the same customers and wallets. | Hedge funds are dipping their toes in advertising thanks to recent changes in S.E.C. regulations. | Banker go-to GrubHub Seamless files for an I.P.O. | The Fed finds vitriol among Wall Street’s financiers.
snippet: Facebook’s deal to acquire WhatsApp shows that competition has never been more intense between technology companies fighting for the same customers and wallets. | Hedge funds are dipping their toes in advertising thanks to recent changes in S.E.C....
lead_paragraph: TECH’S NEW FEEDING FRENZY  |  As soon as Facebook announced on Wednesday that it would acquire WhatsApp, a text messaging start-up, for up to $19 billion, almost everyone asked the same question: Why? What it boils down to is Facebook’s fear of missing out (F.O.M.O., for you cool kids). “Today, with Google, Facebook and others all fighting for the same customers and wallets, the competition has never been more intense, and big companies have never had to act so quickly — and with such conviction — to avoid being left behind,” David Gelles writes in DealBook. But the deal has raised fears that, by valuing the number of users above revenue, Facebook is inflating another dot-com bubble.

headline.main: Tech’s New Feeding Frenzy

abstract: NBC announced it would resurrect the onetime hit science-fiction series as “Heroes Reborn,” a 13-episode series in 2015.
snippet: NBC announced it would resurrect the onetime hit science-fiction series as “Heroes Reborn,” a 13-episode series in 2015.
lead_paragraph: They’re coming back: once-dead television series, that is — revived as so-called event series by networks discovering a form that has distinguished cable drama for much of the past decade. The latest example is the onetime hit science-fiction series “Heroes,” which NBC announced it would resurrect as “Heroes Reborn,” a 13-episode series in 2015. The network used its platform of the Winter Olympics to tease out the announcement on Saturday, running a brief promotion. The news release that followed on Saturday night confirmed a few details: Tim Kring, who created the original “Heroes” in the 2006 television season, will be back as the executive producer. Before that, NBC is to create a digital series that will introduce the new story and characters. (Some original cast members may return.) Jennifer Salke, NBC’s president for entertainment, said in a statement that most details about the new version would be “appropriately shrouded in mystery.” Exactly when the show might appear is not known. Perhaps NBC will wait to see how the most immediate progenitor of the idea, Fox’s revival of “24,” fares this summer. CBS fashioned a hit last summer out of “Under the Dome” and has another such event-style short-run sci-fi series, “Extant,” with Halle Berry, planned for this summer.

headline.main: NBC to Bring Back ‘Heroes’ in New Form
headline.print_headline: NBC to Bring Back ‘Heroes’ in New Form

lead_paragraph: With its extraordinary swoop on WhatsApp last week, Facebook proved its stock is not so different from the crypto-currency of the moment, Bitcoin. They can both be used for certain, specific purposes. Neither is backed by a government. Both depend on vast networks of individuals. And their worth reflects demand, which is based on murky fundamentals. The trick: monetize them while they still have value.

headline.main: Facebook Stock Not So Different Than Bitcoin

lead_paragraph: BITCOIN’S SILVER LINING  |  The apparent collapse of Mt. Gox, the most prominent Bitcoin exchange, late Monday night naturally stirred outrage and panic. After all, a document circulating widely in the Bitcoin world said the company had lost 744,000 Bitcoins — about 6 percent of Bitcoins in circulation — worth more than $300 million at current exchange rates. But Bitcoin’s latest troubles did little to shake the confidence of many, and indeed, the virtual currency’s stumble may provide just the spark it needs to become a more mature part of the financial system, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.

headline.main: A Silver Lining in Bitcoin’s Stumble

lead_paragraph: SENATE SCRUTINIZES CREDIT SUISSE OVER HIDDEN ASSETS  |  A Senate panel criticized Credit Suisse at a hearing on Wednesday, contending that the Swiss bank helped as many as 22,000 Americans hide an estimated $10 billion to $12 billion in assets from the United States tax authorities, Annie Lowrey writes in DealBook. The Senate hearing, the result of a two-year investigation into practices at the bank from 2001 through 2008, followed a scathing report issued on Tuesday by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations that at times read like a legal thriller for its bizarre details on the lengths the bank went to aid Americans in tax evasion.

abstract: Over the past 15 years, something palpable has begun to change at big companies, Tony Schwartz writes. They are awakening to a larger perspective and a bigger view of the role they play in the world.
snippet: Over the past 15 years, something palpable has begun to change at big companies, Tony Schwartz writes. They are awakening to a larger perspective and a bigger view of the role they play in the world.
lead_paragraph: For years, I’ve listened to chief executives of large companies pay dutiful lip service to concepts like corporate social responsibility, investing in the communities they operate in, treating employees as their most precious asset and living their values. Mostly, it comes off as so much canned public posturing — boxes to be checked off, rather than any sort of deep commitment.

headline.main: A Purpose Beyond Profit

abstract: The electronic cigarette maker NJOY received a $70 million capital injection from a group of investors including Brookside Capital and Morgan Stanley Investment Management, in the latest vote of confidence for a fast-growing industry.
snippet: The electronic cigarette maker NJOY received a $70 million capital injection from a group of investors including Brookside Capital and Morgan Stanley Investment Management, in the latest vote of confidence for a fast-growing industry.
lead_paragraph: Even as electronic cigarettes draw the scrutiny of regulators around the world, investors are seeing potential in the fledgling industry.

headline.main: NJOY, E-Cigarette Maker, Receives Funding Valuing It at $1 Billion

abstract: Regional airlines have complained they cannot find qualified pilots and might need to cut back service as a result.
snippet: Regional airlines have complained they cannot find qualified pilots and might need to cut back service as a result.
lead_paragraph: While some regional airlines have reported difficulties hiring new pilots in the last year, a government watchdog said on Friday that it had found “mixed evidence” that the industry was actually facing a shortage of qualified pilots.

headline.main: G.A.O. Finds Little Evidence Pilots Are in Short Supply
